docs.lead_paragraph: With Congress grappling to unify House and Senate health bills, Tom Daschle, the former Senate majority leader, was on the West Coast Wednesday, making his predictions for the final bill. Mr. Daschle was the luncheon speaker at the JPMorgan health care conference in San Francisco, an annual event that attracts thousands of executives from biotechnology and other medical companies and the fund managers who invest in their stocks. Mr. Daschle, of course, was to be President Obama's health czar, before his appointment was derailed last year by a tax scandal.

headline.main: Daschle Handicaps the Final Health Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congressional leaders grappled this week to unify House and Senate health bills, Tom Daschle, the former Senate majority leader, was on the West Coast, making his predictions for the final bill. Mr. Daschle was the luncheon speaker at the JPMorgan health care conference in San Francisco, an annual event that attracts thousands of executives from biotechnology and other medical companies and the fund managers who invest in their stocks.

headline.main: A Crystal Ball on Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: We have asked health care experts of differing political perspectives to address two questions: Why is health care in the United States so expensive? And will the legislation emerging in Washington take sufficient steps to control costs? Here is a condensed version of the response from Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee. The full version is posted online.
docs.abstract: condensed version of response from Sen Charles Grassley on quetion of why health care in US is so expensive and whether emerging legislation will take sufficient steps to control costs; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The leader of New York City's huge public hospital system warned this week that the health care bills in Congress would burden safety-net hospitals by failing to provide coverage for uninsured immigrants while also reducing federal payments for indigent care. In a conference call with reporters, Alan D. Aviles, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, called for Congressional conferees to lift the five-year ban on federal health benefits for legal immigrants. Neither the Senate bill nor the House bill does so.
docs.abstract: New York City Health and Hospitals Corp president Alvin Aviles, in conference call with reporters, warns that health care bills in Congress will burden safety-net hospitals by failing to provide coverage for uninsured immigrants while reducing federal payments for indigent care; encourages Senate to accept House language to allow illegal immigrants to buy health coverage on new government exchanges at full cost (S)
